talking today about rapid radio reversing and and this is reverse engineering of Digital radio
communication systems and in particular doing over-the-air reverse engineering so uh
there are a lot of ways for reverse engineer things there a lot of people think of reverse engineering as being a
software discipline some people think of reverse engineering as being a hardware discipline but I'm talking about reverse
engineering of radio signals uh so figuring out how a radio communication
system works or how our protocol Works uh simply by making observations of the over-the-air signals and not at directly
attacking Hardware or software uh simply by observing radio signals and uh
interacting with the system that way so uh uh I I want to talk in particular
today about an approach to radio reversing that uses both softwar defined
radio techniques and non-software defined radio techniques and uh software
defined radio is of course the uh the technique of using Digital Signal process processing to uh Implement radio
functions in software that would otherwise have to be implemented in hardware and software defined radio is
the most powerful tool for for wireless reverse engineering it is the tool that
you need to get to know if you want to be an expert Wireless reverse engineer if you want to be able to analyze any
radio system Under the Sun then you need to be familiar with SDR but there are a
lot of I communication systems especially these days huge prol proliferation of lowcost
lowspeed digital Radio Systems in things uh you know ranging from industrial
settings home settings Etc and many of these things can be uh implemented or
their Communications can be implemented using non SDR Tools in particular using
wireless transceiver ic's that are capable of of implementing uh Digital
radio communications uh just on a single chip so sometimes those tools are more
appropriate or easier to use for a particular job and I want to show you
today a uh an example of how you can reverse engineer a radio system using
SDR for parts of the process of reversing where it's most convenient and
other tools tools for parts of the process uh where that's more convenient
um the the SDR platform I'm using today is hack rf1 I like it because I designed
it so I'm totally biased uh but it it serves as uh really just an example uh

that I'm using and uh it it digitizes uh bandw I'm going to I'm
going to be using it just as a receiver not as a transmitter today uh and so as
a receiver what it does is you connect an antenna to it and it samples or
digitizes the radio waveform that it's receiving and then gives me over USB uh
connection to my host computer uh a digital signal that is representative of
the analog waveform kind of like a sound card but about a thousand times faster so that it can sample radio waveforms
instead of sound waveforms and uh the great thing that SDR allows us to do is
that it um it it completely represents what happen it captures
everything that happens in a radio signal or over the air uh within a certain bandwidth at a certain frequency
over the captur period of time so it gives us sort of a chunk of information
about the radio spectrum that that is uh that is sort of a a complete description
as opposed to just an interpretation and uh we'll see we'll see what that looks like in a little bit
and SDR has a number of strengths that I I mentioned and in particular the the greatest strength is that it's Universal
you can Implement uh any kind of modulation with software defined radio
because it uh it is completely describing everything that happens in that bandwidth for a period of time and
so any modulation that that fits within that fixed amount of bandwidth um can be
implemented with a software modem uh in in software on on my
laptop and it's SDR when you are doing reverse engineering it's particularly
handy uh it makes it easy to detect the precise frequency of transmission of the system it makes it easy to reverse
engineer the modulation to detect or figure out what the modulation is
and SDR also is extremely good at replay I can capture a radio signal and replay
it without even having to analyze it just like hitting record on a tape recorder and then playing it again so it
has a bunch of strengths that are really nice for reverse engineer but it has some weaknesses too SDR has a a steep
learning curve it it really does take a lot of effort to learn all you need to
know about software defined radio uh I do a two-day class that is very intense
and just kind of gets people going up this curve uh so that they can uh start
to experiment with things on their own but uh really you you need to learn a lot about digital signal processing uh
in order to effectively use software defined radio to reverse engineer arbitrary wireless communication systems
um and it's really good at dealing with the physical layer but once you start going up the protocol stack once you
start dealing with packet data as opposed to waveform data uh it becomes
more difficult to use and it's slower uh for the reverse engineer it's slower to
use uh SDR once you start going up above the physical layer compared to some non
SDR tools now this is the tool that I'm going to use as my example for uh non
SDR this is yard STI one and once again this is a board that I designed so I'm

products um so including the including one that I'll be reversing today for you

wireless transceiver ic's that are on the market is that they provide a digit
modem on a chip so all the modulation and demodulation is done in Hardware not
in software with SDR we do that stuff in software with something like this we do
